'''Tharbad''' was a ford<ref name="pat">{{PE|17}}, entry S ''pat-'', p. 34</ref> and fortified town<ref>{{PM|XNotes}}, note 76</ref><ref name="South">{{FR|South}}, p. 274</ref><ref name="UI">{{HM|UI}}, entry ''Tharbad'', p. 15</ref> at the river [[Gwathló]] on the southern border of [[Eriador]]<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, first paragraph, p. 1039</ref>.

==Geography==
Tharbad was located on the southern border of [[Eriador]] a few miles downstream from the confluence of the river [[Hoarwell]] and the river [[Glanduin]], which formed the river Gwathló.<ref name="Map">{{FR|Map}}</ref> The lower part of the river [[Glanduin]] was a fenland called the [[Swanfleet]] and the natural state of the upper [[Gwathló]] near Tharbad was a slow, wide river that spread into a fenland.<ref name="Glanduin">{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Glanduin</ref> Ships with a smaller draught could be sailed or rowed up the Gwathló as far as Tharbad.<ref>{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Gwathló, first paragraph</ref>

The land around Tharbad was later drained, and dykes were built to construct a great port<ref name="fifth">{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Gwathló, fifth paragraph</ref> for seagoing ships,<ref name="Author">{{UT|6d}} discussion of the name Glanduin, Author's note</ref> a bridge,<ref name="Glanduin" /> forts on great earthworks on both sides of the river to guard the bridge<ref name="Author" />, and long causeways on both sides of the Gwathló and Mitheithel on which the road ran to the bridge of Tharbad<ref name="Glanduin" />.

After its construction by the [[Númenóreans]], the [[North-South Road]] crossed the river Gwathló at Tharbad.<ref name="Map" />

==History==
===Second Age===
In the early [[Second Age]], the river [[Glanduin]] was the southern border of the [[Noldor]]in realm of [[Eregion]].<ref name="Glanduin" />

Before the year  {{SA|800}}, [[Tar-Aldarion|Aldarion]], the son of King [[Tar-Meneldur]] of Númenor, built the haven [[Vinyalondë]] – which means "New Haven" in [[Quenya]] – at the mouth of the river Gwathló as a point where he could obtain timber and repair his ships in [[Middle-earth]]. This was because his father had decreed a curb on the felling of trees in Númenor for the purpose of shipbuilding.<ref>{{UT|Wife}}</ref>

After he took the sceptre in {{SA|883}}<ref>{{UT|4a}}, ''Chronology'', second paragraph</ref>, the King of [[Númenor]], [[Tar-Aldarion]] traveled up the River Gwathló as far as Tharbad and met [[Galadriel]] there.<ref>{{UT|Wife}}, ''The Further Course of the Narrative'', fourth paragraph</ref> It is not known if Tharbad was just a ford or if somebody already settled at Tharbad at the time of their meeting.

The [[Númenóreans]] constructed a small harbour at the river's estuary to exploit the local timber: '', 'the New Haven', which was later called [[Lond Daer]]<ref name="GC" />.''<!-- The comma after "local timber:" should be removed, and I'm not sure what is going on with the italicization here. I'm going to leave it alone and either come back to it later or have someone else revisit it. -->

Before {{SA|1695}},<ref name="fourth">{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Gwathló, fourth paragraph</ref> the Númenóreans had devastated the forests below Tharbad by felling trees to obtain timber to build ships. The local population who had lived in those forests had initially been in awe of the Númenóreans, but had become hostile to them and attacked and ambushed them when the felling of trees became devastating. In return, the Númenóreans treated their attackers as enemies.<ref name="third">{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Gwathló, third paragraph</ref> It is possible that the Númenóreans built the forts at the haven of Lond Daer and along the banks of the river Gwathló, because of those conflicts with the native population. The surviving native population fled from [[Enedwaith]] to the [[Misty Mountains]] in the east, and from [[Minhiriath]] to the dark woods of the cape of [[Eryn Vorn]].<ref name="third" />.

After the invasion of [[Eriador]] by [[Sauron]], the exiled native population who had previously lived in the forests along the Gwathló welcomed Sauron and hoped that he would defeat the Númenóreans. Sauron knew that the haven of Lond Daer and its shipyards were important to the Númenóreans. As a consequence, he used the exiled natives as spies and guides for his raiding parties who started fires in the woods and burned the great wood-stores of the Númenóreans.<ref name="fourth" />

During the war in Eriador, Sauron did not have enough troops to spare for assaults on the forts of the Númenóreans at the haven of Vinyalondë and along the banks of the river Gwathló.<ref name="fourth" /> By {{SA|1700}}, Sauron had destroyed the Elven realm of Eregion and conquered all of Eriador except [[Rivendell]], where he had left strong forces to prevent Elrond to attack him in the rear and had reached the river [[Lhûn]],<!-- "...where he had left strong forces to prevent Elrond to attack him in the rear and had reached the river Lhûn..." Should this say "to prevent Elrond from attacking him in the rear"? Or is Sauron preventing Elrond from doing something so that he can attack Elrond in the rear? --> which was defended by the Elves of the realm of [[Lindon]] and by Númenórean forces that had been stationed in Lindon. Additional forces of Sauron approached from the south-east and were in Enedwaith at the crossing of Tharbad, which was only lightly held.<ref name="GC">{{UT|Concerning}}</ref> It is not known if there were Númenórean forts at the crossing of Tharbad or whether the crossing of Tharbad was lightly held by the Númenóreans or by forces of Sauron.

After a great fleet commanded by the Númenórean admiral [[Ciryatur]] landed with troops from Númenór in {{SA|1700}}, the forces of Sauron were defeated and driven back to the south-east to the river [[Baranduin]]. After another defeat at the [[Sarn Ford]], they were driven back further to the south-east to the river Gwathló, where the forces of Sauron were reinforced by his force at Tharbad. However, Ciryatur had sent a part of his fleet to the haven of Lond Daer and landed a strong Númenórean force there that attacked the forces of Sauron in his rear in the [[Battle of the Gwathló]].<ref name="GC" /> It is not known if the forces of Sauron that had approached from the south-east were still on the southern bank of the river Gwathló in Enedwaith at Tharbad, or whether they had already crossed to the northern side of the river. It is also not known if the forces of Sauron that retreated from Sarn Ford had already crossed the river to its southern side at Tharbad and where at the Gwathló the Battle of the Gwathló took place. In the Battle of the Gwathló, the forces of Sauron were utterly routed and Sauron only barely managed to escape with a small force to [[Calenardhon]].<ref name="GC" />

Tharbad is not mentioned in surviving records for more than 1600 years after the Battle of the Gwathló.<!-- Citation needed -->

===Late Second Age and Third Age===
It is probable that Tharbad became part of the kingdom of [[Arnor]] in {{SA|3320}}, when the kingdoms of Arnor and [[Gondor]] were founded. This is because in the earlier centuries of Arnor and Gondor<ref name="NM">{{NM|P3xxii}}, p. 378</ref><ref name="RC">{{HM|RC}}, p. 650</ref><ref name="VT">{{VT|42a}}</ref>, the region of Enedwaith between the Gwathló and the [[Isen]] belonged to neither of those two kingdoms<ref name="Glanduin" />, and the Gwathló was the eastern border of Arnor and the Isen was the western border of Gondor<ref name="Isen">{{UT|11c}}, note to the text, first paragraph</ref>.

In the early days of the kingdoms of Arnor and Gondor, a seaport where seagoing ships could dock was constructed and a fort was built on great earthworks on both sides of the Gwathló at Tharbad to protect the bridge.<ref name="Author" /> Both kingdoms together constructed the bridge at Tharbad, and the long causeways on both sides of the Gwathló on which the [[North-South Road]], the main route of transport between the two kingdoms except by sea, ran through the fens in Minhiriath and Enedwaith to the bridge.<ref name="Glanduin" /> By the year {{TA|2}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2, p. 1085</ref>, the North-South-Road from Gondor to Arnor already existed, but [[Isildur]], who was in haste, chose to take the shorter route north from [[Osgiliath]] up the [[Vales of Anduin]] to the [[High Pass]] over the [[Misty Mountains]] to return to the Elven refuge of [[Rivendell]], where he had left his wife and his youngest [[Valandil (King of Arnor)|son]].<ref>{{UT|7a}}, note 6, p. 360</ref>.

Until the decay of Arnor, both kingdoms shared an interest in Enedwaith, but were mainly concerned with the maintenance of the North-South Road, the bridge at the fortified town of Tharbad, and of the long causeways on which the road ran.<ref name="Glanduin" /> There were no permanent settlements of people of Númenórean origin in Enedwaith,<ref name="Glanduin" /> except at Tharbad,<ref name="NM" /><ref name="RC" /><ref name="VT" /> where a large garrison of soliders, mariners, engineers<ref name="Glanduin" />, and river-wardens were stationed.<ref name="NM" /><ref name="RC" /><ref name="VT" /> In addition, drainage works were built and maintained, and the banks of the rivers [[Mitheithel]] and Gwathló were strengthened.<ref name="NM" /><ref name="RC" /><ref name="VT" />

When the Kingdom of Arnor was divided in {{TA|861}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 861, p. 1085</ref> [[Minhiriath]], the region between the river [[Baranduin]] and the river Gwathló, became a part of [[Cardolan]], one of the three successor states of Arnor.<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kingdom and the Dúnedain'', first paragraph, p. 1039</ref> As a consequence, Tharbad probably became a part of Cardolan.

From about {{TA|1150}}, the [[Stoors]], a tribe of hobbits, migrated to and settled in<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1150, p. 1085</ref> the area between Tharbad and the borders of Dunland,<ref>{{FR|Hobbits}}, p. 3</ref> but they left around {{TA|1630|n}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year ''c.'' 1630, p. 1085</ref>.

After the [[Great Plague]] spread north-west from Gondor in {{TA|1636}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1636, p. 1086</ref> most of the people of Cardolan died, especially in Minhiriath.<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kingdom and the Dúnedain'', entry for king Argeleb II, p. 1041</ref> After that, Minhiriath was almost completely deserted,<ref name="SecondParagraph">{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name Gwathló, second paragraph</ref>, but some survivors of the Plague continued to live in Tharbad. After the decay and receding of the kingdom of Arnor, which had originally included Minhiriath,<ref name="NM" /><ref name="RC" /><ref name="VT" /> Enedwaith became a part of Gondor during the days of the [[King of Gondor|Kings of Gondor]]. Like before, Gondor was mainly concerned with the maintenance and patrolling of the North-South-Road.<ref name="Isen" /> As a consequence, it is possible that the town of Tharbad became a part of Gondor. However, after the [[Great Plague]] of {{TA|1636}}, the region fell quickly into decay and turned back into wild fenlands long before the [[War of the Ring]].<ref name="Glanduin" />

The survivors of the Great Plague remained in Tharbad, and the North-South-Road continued to be an important trade route for hundreds of years. When the days of the kings in Arnor and Gondor ended between {{TA|1975}} and {{TA|2050|n}} after the fall of [[Arthedain]] in {{TA|1974|n}} and the vanishing of the last king of Gondor [[Eärnur]] at [[Minas Morgul]] in {{TA|2050}} and the decline of Gondor started, the nearby native [[Dunlendings]], as well as the people left in Tharbad no doubt, ceased in fact to be subjects of Gondor, the North-South-Road was no longer maintained in Enedwaith, the bridge in Tharbad became ruinous so that the Gwathló had to be crossed at a ford at the former location of the bridge.<ref name="Isen" /><!-- Second sentence is a huge run-on and needs to be broken up into separate sentences. -->

After the [[Fell Winter]] of {{TA|2911}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2911, p. 1089</ref> in {{TA|2912}}, Enedwaith and Minhiriath were devastated by great floods and Tharbad was ruined and deserted<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2912, p. 1089</ref>.

Over a century later in {{TA|3018}},<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3018, 4 July and 24 October</ref> the North-South Road no longer existed except for the crumbling remains of the causeways on both sides of the river, and the river was crossed by [[Boromir]] on a ford that was formed by the ruins of the bridge.<ref name="GC" /> The ford was so dangerous<ref name="GC" /> that Boromir lost his horse when he crossed the river at the ford.<ref>{{FR|Farewell}}, p. 374</ref>

Before 22 September {{TA|3018}}, the [[Ringwraiths]] cross the Greyflood on their way to the [[Shire]].<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3018, 22 September, the reach the Sarn Ford on that day, p. 1091</ref>

On 27 September {{TA|3018}} Gandalf crossed the Greyflood<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3018, 27 September, p. 1091</ref> with his horse [[Shadowfax]] at Tharbad.<ref>{{HM|RC}}, p. 552 citing from ''The Hunt for the Ring'', Marquette manuscript 4/2/33</ref>
Others occasionally crossed the ruined bridge - at their peril - including the Ringwraiths, servants and spies of [[Saruman]], as well as the [[Rangers of the North]] who sought [[Aragorn]] in Rohan in {{TA|3019|n}}.

After the War of the Ring at the end of the [[Third Age]], the North-kingdom of Arnor was reestablished by Aragorn II.<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, p. 1042</ref> It is probable that the town of Tharbad and its bridge were rebuilt. [[Gandalf]] announced that the [[Greenway]] would be opened again, and that there would be people and fields where there was wilderness before and that there would be room enough for people between the Isen and the Greyflood.<ref>{{RK|Homeward}}, p. 993</ref>

==Etymology==
''Tharbad'' is a [[Sindarin]] name. It means "road-crossing".<ref name="UI" /> It is composed of the elements ''thar'' ("across", "over") and  ''pad'' ("walk", "step").<ref>{{PE|17}}, entries S ''thar-'' and S ''pad-'', p. 34</ref> Its original meaning is said to have been "the Stepping Stones". Tharbad was originally a ford over which one could walk.<ref>{{PE|17}}, entry S ''thar-'', p. 34</ref> The name Tharbad was already used for the ford before the town was established.<ref name="pat" />

==Portrayal in adaptations==
[[File:The Lord of the Rings Online - Tharbad.jpg|thumb|right|Tharbad in ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'']]
'''2022: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:First built by the Númenóreans as a ford and settlement, Tharbad has been rebuilt over the many centuries of its existence. Its position upon the river [[Gwathló]] marks the boundary between the [[Cardolan]] and [[Swanfleet]] regions: thus making it a landmark in both regions. It is also the dividing point between the [[Greenway]] and the [[Old South Road]]. The ruins are currently occupied by [[Orcs]]. An expedition of hopeful settlers from [[Bree-land]] camp nearby on the Cardolan side.
